text: [Music]
my name is bill ponder I'm the falconer
for medieval times in New Jersey and
about you know 25 years ago I decided to
change careers and and at the age of 38
I decided to run away and join the
circus and Here I am
you're usually training birds that are
juvenile they're newly born you know
just at the point where they would be
leaving the nest learning how to fly
that's the age that the parents spend a
lot of time showing them how to fend for
themselves in nature and then it really
is a matter of weeks and if you if it
takes a matter of months you're not
consistent it depends on the consistency
of the trainer if you do the thing same
things the same way every day the birds
catch on pretty quick they learn from
success and they learn from failure and
success is repeated and failure is
discarded when I handle these birds
everything I do with them I approach it
as I want them to learn that this is the
right way to to behave and he's flying
around in there at highway speeds he's
going pretty fast we're not keeping pets
we're we're training active healthy
animals our detractors accused us of
starving the birds and that's farthest
thing from the truth so what you're
basically doing is you're giving them as
good a nutritious diet as possible as
much exercise as you can and you're
giving them the opportunities to do what
comes naturally they they they need to
fly to stay healthy and we have
basically the responsibility to give
them that opportunity
the guy with the food
[Music]
